questions.question: Consider a Best-First Search algorithm applied to a search space with a branching factor of 3. If the maximum depth of the search space is 5, how many nodes will be expanded in the worst case scenario?
If h1 and h2 are two admissible heuristics for a given problem, then heuristic h3(n) = max(h1(n), h2(n)) for all states, n, must also be admissible.

explanations.a: Suppose h*(n) is the true cost. It is given that h1(n) <= h*(n) and h2(n) <= h*(n) for all states. Since h3(n) <= h1(n) and h3(n) <= h2(n), then h3(n) <= h*(n).

questions.question: Consider the problem of getting from Iasi to Fagaras in the simplified map of Romania (Figure 1). Which of the following will occur using BFS?

answers.a: An optimal path will be found from Iasi to Fagaras.
answers.b: A non-optimal path will be found from Iasi to Fagaras.

explanations.c: The algorithm will be stuck in a loop between Iasi and Neamt.

questions.question: In a Best-First Search algorithm, which of the following evaluation functions is not suitable for solving a maze navigation problem?

answers.a: Number of steps taken from the start to the current node
answers.b: Manhattan distance from the current node to the goal node
answers.c: Euclidean distance from the current node to the goal node
answers.d: Randomly generated value assigned to each node

explanations.d: Randomly generated values can overestimate the cost.
